title: Executive Order Authorizing Additional Sanctions With Respect to Iran
summary: Imposed additional sanctions on Iran's energy and petrochemical sectors and expanded financial sanctions.
plain_language_summary:
New Iran Sanctions Unlikely to Affect Universities

Overview: President Obama issued an executive order imposing new sanctions on Iran's energy, petrochemical, and financial sectors in response to Iran's nuclear program. The order expands existing sanctions but does not appear to introduce any new requirements directly relevant to higher education institutions.

Bottom Line: While universities should review the details, this order is unlikely to require any immediate changes to current practices or operations for most institutions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Finances: No expected impact on university financing, endowments, tuition, or other core funding

Research: Unlikely to affect federal research grants or international research partnerships

Enrollment: Does not change student visa policies or introduce new restrictions on Iranian student enrollment

Important Dates:

  • 07/30/2012: Executive order issued

Affected Departments:

Finance Office, Office of Sponsored Projects, International Programs Office

Action Plan:

Action Required: No, unless the institution has significant investments or business ties in Iran's energy, petrochemical or financial sectors, which is unlikely.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review order to confirm no impact to current practices

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor any clarifying guidance from Department of Education or other agencies

Long-term Considerations:

  • Stay informed of any future changes to Iran sanctions that may be more relevant to higher education

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No additional personnel needed

Budget: No budget impact

Technology: No new technology required

External Expertise: Unlikely to require outside legal or subject matter expertise
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Executive order authorizing additional sanctions on Iran's energy, petrochemical, and financial sectors. Unlikely to directly impact most university operations.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order 13622 - Additional Iran Sanctions and Implications for Higher Education

Overview: President Obama issued Executive Order 13622 on July 30, 2012 authorizing additional sanctions with respect to Iran. The order targets Iran's energy and petrochemical sectors, prohibiting certain financial and material support to Iran. It also expands existing financial sanctions. While significant for U.S. foreign policy, the order does not appear to create new compliance obligations for colleges and universities.

Bottom Line: This executive order primarily concerns trade and investment restrictions on Iran's energy, petrochemical, and financial sectors. There are no evident new requirements that would impact core university functions of education, research, or campus operations. However, institutions should still review the order to assess any unique implications based on their international activities and investments.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

The U.S. has progressively expanded sanctions on Iran since the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996, targeting Iran's energy sector and nuclear program. This order builds on Iran sanctions in the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability, and Divestment Act of 2010 and other executive orders.

Legal Framework:

The President issued this order under the authority of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), the National Emergencies Act (NEA), and section 301 of title 3, United States Code. It is part of the broader U.S. sanctions regime against Iran.

Higher Education Context:

While this order does not introduce new regulations for higher education, universities must continue to navigate a complex landscape of export controls (EAR, ITAR), sanctions, and foreign investment restrictions that can impact international programs, research, and transactions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Financing and Investment: Universities do not typically invest directly in Iran's energy or petrochemical sectors. Endowments and retirement funds may have some exposure through index funds or other vehicles, but the order does not require divestment

Research and Intellectual Property: Does not restrict fundamental research or intellectual property rights. Existing export control and sanction regulations still apply to any technology transfer to Iran

International Partnerships: No new constraints on academic partnerships or exchange programs. Visas and student enrollment are not impacted.

Talent Acquisition: Does not affect hiring or recruitment of Iranian faculty, researchers or students beyond existing immigration and visa policies

Supply Chain: Universities generally do not source materials or equipment from Iran's energy and petrochemical sectors. Standard supply chain due diligence should suffice to identify any touchpoints

Important Dates:

  • 07/30/2012: Executive order issued
  • 08/10/2012: Clarifying guidance expected from the Departments of State and Treasury on scope and implementation

Affected Departments:

University Counsel, Research Administration/Sponsored Projects, Export Controls Compliance, Technology Transfer Office, International Programs/Global Partnerships, Enrollment/Admissions, Endowment/Investment Office, Procurement/Supply Chain

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Institutions should document their review of the executive order, any identified exposures, and steps taken to prevent any prohibited transactions or support. Maintain records of supply chain and investment due diligence, international partnership reviews, and any other relevant internal controls.

Technical Analysis:

The order's focus on Iran's energy, petrochemical, and financial sectors means its greatest impact will be on engineering, energy, and finance-related programs and research. Institutions with expertise in nuclear engineering, petroleum, or natural gas need to be particularly attentive.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Implementation requires coordination between research administration, international programs, export compliance, general counsel, enrollment, endowment, and other offices to assess and address the multi-faceted dimensions of engagement with Iran.

Risk Analysis:

The primary risks lie in any direct or indirect support to Iran's energy, petrochemical, or financial sectors through research, partnerships, procurement, or investment. Violations can trigger substantial penalties. However, for most institutions, the likelihood and impact of any non-compliance is relatively low.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

This order does not significantly advantage or disadvantage any particular type of institution. However, universities with deeper international ties, especially in the Middle East, will face higher compliance costs and limitations on potential opportunities.

Long-term Vision:

Despite this order's low immediate impact, the growing array of international sanctions and export regulations creates an increasingly complex environment for higher education's global activities. Institutions will need sustainable risk-based compliance frameworks to support their international ambitions.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities, individually and collectively through associations, should engage with policymakers to ensure that sanction and export control frameworks include appropriate carve-outs for fundamental research and educational activities, while balancing legitimate national security concerns.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No immediate action is required for most institutions. However, universities with significant international activities, particularly in energy-related research or partnerships in the Middle East, would be prudent to review the details of this order to identify any potential exposure.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Circulate order to relevant departments
  • Review international research portfolio and partnerships for any Iran nexus
  • Verify endowment and investment policy compliance
  • Confirm supply chain due diligence for any Iran touchpoints

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor guidance from the Departments of State, Treasury, Education, and other relevant agencies
  • Update policies and procedures as needed
  • Brief senior leadership on any identified risks or exposures

Long-term Considerations:

  • Incorporate into ongoing compliance training and awareness programs
  • Adapt research administration and international partnership processes to flag potential issues
  • Engage with higher education associations to shape constructive enabling policies

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: May require additional staff hours in research administration, international programs, and compliance functions to conduct initial and ongoing reviews. Larger institutions may need full-time compliance officers.

Budget: Costs limited to additional staff time, training, and compliance infrastructure (e.g. software). Unlikely to require significant new expenditures.

Technology: Existing research administration and compliance systems can likely accommodate E.O. requirements. May need to augment international partnership and supply chain management platforms.

External Expertise: Some institutions may require specialized outside counsel to assess specific international exposures and transactions, but this should be limited in most cases.
